qas.question: Who was Algeria's first president, a fervent Nasserist?
What Nasserist usurped the King of Yemen?
Which leader considered Nasser his hero?
What leader took power in Sudan and was inspired by Nasser?

context: To varying degrees, Nasser's statist system of government was continued in Egypt and emulated by virtually all Arab republics, namely Algeria, Syria, Iraq, Tunisia, Yemen, Sudan, and Libya. Ahmed <a0_0>Ben Bella<a0_0/>, Algeria's first president, was a staunch Nasserist. <a1_0>Abdullah al-Sallal<a1_0/> drove out the king of North Yemen in the name of Nasser's pan-Arabism. Other coups influenced by Nasser included those that occurred in Iraq in July 1958 and Syria in 1963. <a2_0>Muammar Gaddafi<a2_0/>, who overthrew the Libyan monarchy in 1969, considered Nasser his hero and sought to succeed him as "leader of the Arabs". Also in 1969, <a3_0>Colonel Gaafar Nimeiry<a3_0/>, a supporter of Nasser, took power in Sudan. The <a4_0>Arab Nationalist Movement<a4_0/> (ANM) helped spread Nasser's pan-Arabist ideas throughout the Arab world, particularly among the Palestinians, Syrians, and Lebanese, and in South Yemen, the Persian Gulf, and Iraq. While many regional heads of state tried to emulate Nasser, Podeh opined that the "parochialism" of successive Arab leaders "transformed imitation [of Nasser] into parody".
